question: Skate-boarders I don't mind, even though they dress like fuckin' idiots, but when I see some pin-head on rollerblades, I get the definite urge to grease the grill of my car with 'em.
answer: Keep your eyes peeled.

question: What about them?
answer: Too old. If you ever had an idea it would die of malnutrition. First those blue hairs then some Spic. Leave this to me. I know people. It's my job. I'm a people person.

question: What the fuck are you looking for?
answer: I'm looking for them.

question: Where?
answer: Right there.

question: I gotta make a phone call, Lynn. Do you see a phone? Come on, you. Haven't you ever seen anybody kiss like that?
answer: On TV.

question: You never saw your Mom and me kiss like that? Hey, it's OK to talk about her. You can talk about her all you want. You know that, don't you? So, come on. You never saw us kiss like that?
answer: No way.

question: Uh, sure. What's, what's the problem? Will a driver's license do?
answer: That'll do just fine.

question: Is this about those kids? Look, I'm sorry about that. But they darn near...
answer: You're from Santa Maria, Mr. Watson?

question: Hey, would you look at this crazy car? Everybody has their own radio. What do you think of that?
answer: Everybody does?

question: Yep. And you can listen to it without anybody else listening. Let's try it out. This is what they call the jack. Hi, Jack!
answer: Laughs.

question: It goes in that little hole.
answer: Let me do it. It's loud!

question: Get your hands off her.
answer: Mr. Watson, you're not paying attention. Your daughter's life depends on you. Do you understand that?

question: Yes, yes, I understand.
answer: Good. This is for you. In it there is a picture of a woman and an itinerary. It is her itinerary. She is presently - are you listening, Mr. Watson?

question: Yes, I'm listening.
answer: She is presently at the Bonaventure Hotel. That's right near here. When you leave this van you will get yourself a cab and take it to the Bonaventure Hotel. Then you will take this. ...and you will kill the woman whose picture is in there. Not just shoot her, mind,! kill her. I'd recommend you empty the gun into her. Close up. Got all that?

question: You're out of your mind.
answer: What's your point?

question: I will do no such thing.
answer: Yes, you will, Mr. Watson.

question: Yes, you will, Mr. Watson.
answer: Don't worry. We'll take good care of the kid.

question: It is now 12:16. If the woman in the picture is alive at 1:30... ...I call my partner, your daughter is dead. And what happens if I don't call you?
answer: I kill her anyway.

question: Just like Power Rangers.
answer: Let's test this thing. You on?

question: Reading you.
answer: You'11 need some cash. I'll hang onto this for the time being. Oh, and... You'll need these. Get moving, Mr. Watson. Time's a wastin'. You talk to a cop, you even look at a cop too long and your daughter is dead. Do it.

question: Where to, sir?
answer: The Bonaventure. The Bonaventure Hotel. Do you know where that is?

question: Amtrack?
answer: What?

question: You just come in on Amtrack?
answer: Uh, yes..

question: Business or pleasure?
answer: Business.

question: Where'd you come from?
answer: San Diego.

question: Oh, San Diego? I've thought about moving to San Diego. It's hard to make a living in this town. These short hops. Can't make a dime on 'em. To LAX, Pasadena, then I can make a buck. These little hops cost me money.
answer: Sorry.

question: 'S okay. What do you think?
answer: Huh?

question: Better in San Diego? More opportunity there? What?
answer: I really don't know. I don't live there. I was just visiting...a grave.

question: Aw, too bad. Somebody close?
answer: What?

question: The grave. Somebody close?
answer: Wife. Ex-wife. Almost ex. We were separated. She was thinking about a divorce. Look...I've... I've got a problem. A big problem...

question: Oh, yeah? Jesus! Watch it, buddy! I'd love to hear about your problem, but the ride's over. Three-fifty. Three-fifty. I hope your problem doesn't have anything to do with my three-fifty.
answer: Right. Right.

question: What do I want with an accountant? You bet.
answer: Oh, my God. Oh, no. Oh, shit. Oh, sweet Jesus... Could you tell me where the Emerald Bay Room is? Oh, thanks. Thanks a lot.

question: Excuse me, is the...thing over? Eleanor Grant is gone?
answer: Check your itinerary. Move along.

question: This says "invitation only".
answer: Of course you're invited. You're a big donor to the campaign. They love you. This'11 get you in anywhere. Red Elevator. Thirty-fifth floor.

question: Where did you get these? Who are you?
answer: I'm the guy who's going to kill your daughter if you don't get moving.

question: She was right in front of you! What's wrong with you!? Are you 'fucking with me!?
answer: The gun...

question: What about the gun?
answer: It wasn't loaded. I didn't put the bullets in it.

question: That's pretty good.
answer: I've done much better ones than this.

question: You have, huh?
answer: Oh, yes. I'll show you. I have much more colors at home.

question: Having a rough day? Down at the heels as they...? You don't see your face, you don't pay! Having a rough day? Down at the heels as they say? What you need is a shoe shine, shoe shine, shoe shine today. Take ten, take a break, take a seat, take a load off. Put the world in perspective. So, are you a visitor or lucky enough to live in The City of Angels?
answer: I'm...I'm visiting.

question: What do you do, if I may be so bold?
answer: I'm just an accountant.

question: Don't denigrate yourself, my friend. Where would the government be without accountants? They wouldn't know how hard they can squeeze us before we pop, isn't that right? Now you take tips. Time was a tip was between a man and his customer. Not any more. They've figured out what they call a formulae, don't laugh, it ain't for babies. They take your sales, see, and slap a percentile on there, figuring that somewhere between your lies and your bad luck they'll hit on the mean amount, mean meaning "in the middle", but if you ask me it means "just plain mean". Why you can have Uncle Scrooge wring a nickel over your poor out-stretched palm, or Daddy Warbucks dropping pearl stick-pins like manna from heaven, don't make no difference, they'll tax your behind according to that same figure. Doesn't seem quite right., does it?
answer: No. No, it doesn't.

question: It's a load, my friend, but somebody's got to carry it.
answer: I have to do something.

question: What's that? You have to speak up. I'm a little deaf in this ear. Between that and my wooden leg I'm a mess. Compliments of the United States Army Artillery Corps.
answer: I said I have to do something.

question: I'll have you out of here in two shakes o'f a lamb's tail.
answer: Is within himself. Drove me crazy. There must have been one on me. I didn't add up so she left. That's what attracted me to her In the first place. She made up her mind and she did it. She wouldn't sit around waiting for...whatever. She'd do something. She'd do something.

question: Yes, well, you know, for a quality shoe you can't beat a good wingtip. Wears like iron. You're a wise man. There ya' go. Two bucks. You got anything smaller?
answer: Keep it.

question: It's a twenty.
answer: Keep it.

question: Well...thanks muchly...
answer: Can I get out to Flower Street from here?

question: Sure. Go down past the bar. Take you right out there.
answer: Thanks.

question: Thanks.
answer: You get another chance in ten minutes.

question: Then I have time for a drink.
answer: All right, Mr. Watson, but make it just one. I don't want you...

question: So do you, Mr. Watson. You got this under control?
answer: Yeah.

question: It doesn't look like it.
answer: It's under control.

question: It better be.
answer: I oughta throw you after that walkie- talkie but I'm going to give you a break because you're an amateur. Yeah, thanks. Have a cracker. Have a cracker, Mr. Watson. There was this guy. Big guy. Irish- Italian. Red-faced, black-haired, jolly son-of-a-bitch. Nobody could make me laugh like him. We closed more bars together than I can count. He was my pal. I loved that crazy mick, I'm not ashamed to say it. But he was fuck-up. He had this image of himself. Thought he was con man. Always trying to shave the edge. Nickel and dime. I'll always miss him. Tell me why.

question: I oughta throw you after that walkie- talkie but I'm going to give you a break because you're an amateur. Yeah, thanks. Have a cracker. Have a cracker, Mr. Watson. There was this guy. Big guy. Irish- Italian. Red-faced, black-haired, jolly son-of-a-bitch. Nobody could make me laugh like him. We closed more bars together than I can count. He was my pal. I loved that crazy mick, I'm not ashamed to say it. But he was fuck-up. He had this image of himself. Thought he was con man. Always trying to shave the edge. Nickel and dime. I'll always miss him. Tell me why.
answer: What...?

question: Tell me why I miss him.
answer: He's dead?

question: That's right. He's dead. Tell me why.
answer: How should I...?

question: Tell me why he's dead.
answer: You killed him.

question: It is my extreme pleasure this afternoon to introduce to you... ...a woman who can only be characterized as a one-of-a-kind.
answer: Feeling better?

question: An iconoclast with class...
answer: The elevator. You weren't feeling well.

question: A genuine lady who's not afraid to get into the trenches...
answer: Are you better now?

question: My wife always said I had a problem trusting people.
answer: Well, you can trust Eleanor Samara Grant.

question: You don't understand. I'm going to trust you. And you have to trust me.
answer: Yes, you're right, I don't understand.

question: Look...my daughter ... she's going to die...unless you can help me.
answer: Sure, sure, I'll help you. Let me get Mr. White. I'm sure he can assist you, he's our...

question: No! You have to listen to me.
answer: I'm listening, I'm listening.

question: Please...please...you have to believe me... They have my daughter. They want me to kill Eleanor Grant  or they'll kill my daughter.
answer: All right, let's just...let's get security in on this.

question: No! You can't! They're in on it.
answer: I don't see how they could be in on it. They're the best. They're hand- picked.

question: I don't know. One of them is following me. If he knew what I'd just told you they'd... Look, how did I get in here with this!?
answer: I don't know.

question: You've got to trust me. I'm putting my daughter's life in your hands. She's only six. She's just a little girl. Please, please, trust me.
answer: It's a little hard to trust you under the circumstances.

question: You're right, it is. Here. Will you trust me now?
answer: I guess I'll have to. Come on, there's one person we can go to.

question: The man following me has a walkie- talkie. If he sees I'm not here he'll call his partner. I do anything out of line and he'll send the word to kill my daughter.
answer: He'll think you're in the crowd until the end of the speech. Wait a minute.

question: We've got about ten minutes.
answer: Are you sure?

question: I've heard this speech a lot. Come on. We'll take care of him. We will.
answer: But...

question: Trust me. You asked me for help. Let me help. Trust me.
answer: Okay... Hey. I think you better put that away.

question: And on the strength of this story, you bring this man to Brendan's suite? Does that show good judgment, Ms. Brooks? I'm just a friend of Brendan's, but it seems to me...
answer: He brought a gun onto the pool deck.

question: What?
answer: He got onto the pool deck with a gun. How did he get past her Security carrying a

question: I see. Where is this gun? Well, is it real? Do we know anything about it?
answer: It looks real. I don't know anything about guns.

question: I'm not stupid.. I know how this is supposed, to work.
answer: Do you now, Mr. Watson?

question: I kill her - and you kill me.
answer: Keep your voice down.

question: Even if you don't, Her Security men will. How am I supposed to get away?
answer: That's not my problem, Mr. Watson Come back.

question: How do I know you won't kill my daughter once I'm gone?
answer: Come Back....Fucking Radio.

question: And I'm supposed to trust you?
answer: What choice do you have? After you. Look out there! You see the van? You see it?! Come back.

question: Having a rough day? Down at the heels as they say? What you need is a shoe shine, shoe shine, shoe shine today. Take ten, take a break, take a seat, take a load off. Put the world in perspective. So, are you a visitor or are you lucky enough to... You got a complaint?
answer: You remember me?

question: I remember. The big tipper.
answer: Something is going to happen. When it's over you'll know what I was talking about.

question: Oh, man...
answer: Please. Something is going to happen...

question: What? The end of the world? Man, don't give me your mad rap. I'm not a bartender. I don't want to hear it. I raise a family doing this bullshit. Do me a favor. Get your crazy white ass out of my chair.
answer: Please...

question: Yeah, sure, give me a shine... ...shine. I'm putting your toy back in your pocket, Mr. Watson. It's all wound up. Now let's get out your itinerary.
answer: One thirty. California Ballroom.

question: That's right. That gives you... ...twenty-six minutes to get your shit together.
answer: Let me talk to her again.

question: No.
answer: I want'to talk to her.

question: Forget about it.
answer: I talk to her or you can forget about it.

question: Don't you threaten me.
answer: What are you going to do about it, shoot me?

question: You know what I'm gonna do.
answer: What? Walk out there and twist her arm off? It would be a lot less trouble just to let me talk to her.

question: Come Back.
answer: Yeah.

question: Put her on.
answer: What gives?

question: Daddy?
answer: Yes, sweetie, it's me.

question: I'm tired. I want to.go now.
answer: I know you do, honey.

question: Can we go now?
answer: Not just yet, baby. There's...there's something Daddy has to do.

question: To be a hero?
answer: No, honey, not to be a hero. But I want you to remember something for me, all right?

question: All right.
answer: He's doing it for you. No matter what anybody tells you, no matter who they are, he's doing it for you, because he loves you.

question: Will you promise me that?
answer: I promise.

question: All right. Kisses to you.
answer: No...kisses to you.

question: No. Kisses to you.
answer: No, kisses to...

question: Thanks for the tip. Mister, what are you dragging me into?
answer: I'm not dragging you into anything. I don't expect...

question: Cover your mouth.
answer: What?

question: This gorilla's watching you, is that right?
answer: That's right.

question: Then don't let him be seeing you talking to me. I don't want him twisting my arm off. That was your kid on the walkie- talkie?
answer: My daughter. They have her in a van across the street. They say they'll kill her if I don't do something for them.

question: In twenty-five minutes in the California Ballroom.
answer: There was a woman. She was trying to help me. I watched him murder her.

question: What are you supposed to do?
answer: Kill the Governor.

question: I knew I should have packed up and gone home as soon as I got that twenty. What am I supposed to do about this situation?
answer: One of them is in on it. He might even be in charge. Her Security is in on it. There's only one person I know for sure isn't in on it.

question: Who?
answer: The Governor. If I could just talk to her...

question: Oh, Jesus ...
answer: No way, there's nothing you can do to help me.

question: Then why'd you drag me into it?
answer: It's my kid. I've got to...to somehow...do right by my little girl. It's about time I did. I was one of those guys, workaholics. I worked my ass off for them - my wife, my daughter. That's just what I thought I was supposed to do.

question: Yeah, all right, listen...
answer: So when she wanted a divorce...I was...I didn't know what I'd done wrong. I didn't see it. I didn't see it....

question: Why don't you tell me about the early years some other time?
answer: I'm sorry. You understand I don't mind dying if I could save my daughter. I mean that.

question: Yeah, now listen. I can't mess with these shoes any more or it's gonna look funny. You go down get yourself something to drink. Make sure Godzilla there, follows you.
answer: What are you going to do?

question: I haven't the faintest idea. Go on now. I'll get word to you.
answer: If nothing else, someone heard my story. Keep the change.

question: Don't think I won't.
answer: I need a drink. Give me a ...a gingerale?

question: I need a drink. Give me a ...a gingerale?
answer: No shit. If I hear that stop the violence routine one more time I'm going to shoot somebody. They're all the same. You know what bothers me? When they get all weepy eyed about the "ordinary citizen", the "regular Joe", the "normal American". Gimme a break. There ain't no such animal. We're a nation of two hundred forty million special interest groups.

question: Well, I'm just a regular guy.
answer: Is that right?

question: Let's all hope so.
answer: Quick, off with the shoes and pants. Trade with Gustino. The big guy's coming. C'mon, ladies. No time to be shy. Gustino! Drop 'em! And cover up them socks. Man, who dresses you? Meet Irene.

question: Hi.
answer: Irene is going to help.

question: Thank you. Where am I going?
answer: You said there was only one person you knew wasn't in on this thing.

question: Yeah.
answer: You're going to go see her.

question: What!?
answer: You sure she's asleep?

question: What am I supposed to say to her?
answer: It'll come to you. See if you can stop this thing 'fore it gets started. Save us all considerable embarrassment. Irene...?

question: Excuse me...
answer: Who the hell are you?

question: No, please. Mrs. Grant, Governor...I won't hurt you.
answer: My security people are right next door.

question: I appreciate that.
answer: One loud scream will bring them in here instantly. You won't get very far. Think it over.

question: If I were here to hurt you I would have done it already.
answer: That's...a comfort to hear.

question: I have a problem.
answer: Ah.

question: Only you can help me. I'm also sorry to say, my problem is your problem, Mrs. Grant.
answer: I remember you...in the elevator.

question: That's right.
answer: You were very nervous.

question: It was because I had this...in my pocket I need you to listen to me. Carefully. Three lives depend on you listening very carefully to what I have to say.
answer: Of course. But suppose we set up an appointment. I have an important speech to deliver and you're cutting into my nap time.

question: Krista Brooks is dead.
answer: How do you know that?

question: I saw her die. She was shot. With this gun.
answer: You shot her?

question: No.
answer: Who did?

question: I don't know. The only thing I know about him is that he works for your husband.
answer: What?

question: And your husband works for somebody else.
answer: What the hell are you saying?

question: I knew you wouldn't believe me.
answer: I said I'd listen to you, not necessarily believe you. You're telling me my people are in a plot against me. You're telling me my husband wants me killed. What do you expect?

question: I don't blame you. I don't have any proof. But nothing like this occurs in a vacuum. You can't be totally oblivious. You must suspect something. You're doing things which are making people angry. People who have been in power a long time are losing their jobs. You know them better than me. How much does it mean to them? How far would they go to hang onto it? There's only one way to find out for sure. Try to cancel the last speech.
answer: I'd prefer we didn't refer to it as my last speech.

question: It's the last chance they have for me to kill you. Try to get out of it. They won't let you. They can't. Try to change the schedule and you'll know I'm right. What have you got to lose? It comes down to who you trust, them or me? Test them.
answer: I love it when pistolero's talk of trust.

question: This? I've never even fired one.
answer: Indeed. Franco! Franco.' I...I'm afraid I've had a bad dream, Franco.

question: Well?
answer: I don't know.

question: What are you going to do now?
answer: I don't know. I have to get back.

question: What are you going to do!?
answer: This is about power and you haven't got any. There's nothing more you can do. I'm sorry. Thanks for trying.

question: Where is he?
answer: In the john.

question: Get moving.
answer: You' oughta learn to relax. I told you I've got it under control.

question: During a campaign every speech is important. This is free media exposure. Primetime news coverage that we couldn't buy.
answer: What's he doing here?

question: Who, him? Just visiting. He's my friend. And he did help you to get elected, after all.
answer: Don't remind me.

question: What happened here?
answer: Nothing. I broke a lamp.

question: Eleanor, please. I'll put it this way. This speech or a half-dozen rubber chicken-fund raisers. What do you say?
answer: Truth is, besides the headache I've come down with a little lower intestinal havoc. Make my apologies.

question: Come on, El, you're a trooper. I'll get you some Pepto, you'll make one of your patented tributes to the common person, then back to Sacramento. This is no time to lay down on the job. I don't care what the polls say, you can't afford to relax. Look what happened to Bush. Tell you what, if you want to blow off the Sacramento speech, fine. But do this one and we'll get out of the smog.
answer: All right, I'll do it.

question: That's my girl.
answer: But I want to make some changes. Get Krista in here right away won't you?

question: Aw, gee. I sent her on an errand.
answer: You sent my assistant on an errand.

question: I've been a bad boy. Ladies and gentlemen of the press, campaign volunteers, and those of you who were looking for any excuse to take off work for the afternoon... We have with us today the first woman Governor of our great state... Governor Eleanor Samara Grant. What can I say about her....that won't get me in trouble when I get home tonight.
answer: Charlie. Charlie. Charlie, are you reading me?

question: She's a woman who loves our great state.
answer: Charlie... I can't get shit on this stupid radio.

question: A brilliant legislator. ...who will soon win her second term as the greatest Governor California has ever seen!
answer: Somebody's going to ave to run down to the truck. Tell them this radio's fucked. I can't get through. Walkie-Talkies don't work from here. There's too much concrete and stuff.

question: Ladies and gentlemen...
answer: Nothin's getting out.

question: It's time....You read me? I don't hear from you I'm going ahead now.
answer: Why do you keep looking at me?

question: That's my job. I'm your babysitter.
answer: I'm not a baby.

question: You're a big girl, huh?
answer: I'm not a big girl but I'm not a baby.

question: Close your eyes.
answer: Why?

question: I've got something for you.
answer: A surprise?

question: You ask too many questions. You want the surprise or not?
answer: Good afternoon, madam. Hello there, little girl.

question: Hey, hey, what are you doing!?
answer: Just giving you the gift of a clean windshield. Only cost you a dollar.

question: I don't want my windshield cleaned.
answer: You just think you don't want your windshield cleaned.

question: No, I know I don't want it cleaned. Get out of here.
answer: Don't be like that. Think of me as the Moses of dirty windshields leading you through the desert of dead bugs.

question: For the last time, I don't want it cleaned. Now get the hell out of here!
answer: It's already done. I've already done it. You have to pay me now.

question: I don't have to pay you nothin'.
answer: You're going to deny me a lousy dollar after I've sweated like a pig giving you the gift of a clean windsheild?

question: Fuckin' A.
answer: I don't think so.

question: Hey!
answer: I think this is worth a dollar.

question: Goddamnit! Gimme that!
answer: Oh, we'll have to do better than that.

question: You worthless piece of shit! Gimme that! Goddamnit, you fuckin' bum, come here!
answer: Gimme a dollar.

question: Lost my watch.
answer: Any comment at this time would be most premature. Please, we'll have something for you in a couple of hours. Please... I...1 would like to...thank you, Mister Wat... Gene. I would also like to apologize.

question: For what?
answer: For not believing you.

question: Believe me, I don't blame you. This is the Governor, Lynn. Say hello.
answer: You have a very brave father, Lynn.

question: Can we go now?
answer: Of course. I'll get a car to drive you.

question: No, that's... That's OK. We don't need any help. We'll be just fine. Won't we, Lynn?
answer: Good luck.
